intro: Paepalanthus pusillus, commonly known as the dwarf puya, is a flowering plant native to the high Andes of South America. It is a member of the Bromeliaceae family and is characterized by its compact rosette of narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces striking, tubular flowers that are typically red or orange in color, which attract pollinators such as hummingbirds. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is adapted to the harsh conditions of its alpine habitat. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is a subject of interest in botanical research and conservation efforts.
